qas.question: What is the primary use of IRENE?
Can IRENE read vertically modulated information?
Does IRENE require the  ability to touch the media?

context: In some ways similar to the laser turntable is the IRENE <a0_0>scanning machine for disc records<a0_0/>, which images with microphotography in two dimensions, invented by a team of physicists at <a1_0>Lawrence Berkeley Laboratories<a1_0/>. IRENE will <a2_0>retrieve the information<a2_0/> from a laterally modulated monaural grooved sound source <a4_0>without touching the medium<a4_0/> itself, but <a3_0>cannot read vertically modulated information<a3_0/>. This excludes grooved recordings such as cylinders and some radio transcriptions that feature a hill-and-dale format of recording, and stereophonic or quadraphonic grooved recordings, which utilize a combination of the two as well as supersonic encoding for quadraphonic.
